title: Pygmalion
text: Pygmalion loathing their lascivious life, Abhorr'd all womankind, but most a wife: So single chose to live, and shunn'd to wed, Well pleas'd to want a consort of his bed. Yet fearing idleness, the nurse of ill, In sculpture exercis'd his happy skill; And carv'd in iv'ry such a maid, so fair, As Nature could not with his art compare.

title: Daedalus and Icarus
text: In tedious exile now too long detain'd, Daedalus languish'd for his native land: The sea foreclos'd his flight; yet thus he said, Tho' earth and water in subjection laid, O cruel Minos, thy dominion be, We'll go thro' air; for sure the air is free.

title: Midas
text: Now Midas, with his newly-gotten gold, To the rich stream of Pactolus is roll'd: There, as the god commanded, he did lave, And the gold flow'd away within the wave. The king is happy now, his wish is o'er, And all he touches is but dross no more.

title: Actaeon
text: A cave there was, which not the art of man, But Nature's hand had form'd; a secret span Of waters clear, where oft the huntress-maid, In the cool stream her weary limbs had laid. Actaeon hither, while the sun was high, Wand'ring by chance, did all her charms espy.
